Now, option G is Bb × BB. The BB parent will always contribute B, and the Bb parent can contribute B or b. So 75% will get B (from Bb), making the offspring B_ (black), and 25% will get b, making them bb (white). This fits exactly the observed ratio. So G seems promising.

Wait, but let me check another possibility. Option C is bb × Bb, which is the same as G but reversed. It should give the same ratio, right? Because whether the first parent is bb or Bb, the outcome remains the same due to the law of segregation. So C also results in 75% black and 25% white. Hmm, but maybe the parents being Bb × bb is different from bb × Bb? No, both are the same in terms of the possible gametes. The Bb parent can produce B or b, and the bb parent can only produce b. However, since the problem mentions coat color, which is a single gene trait, the cross is likely monohybrid. So the parents must be producing alleles that lead to the observed ratio.

Another way to approach this is to use Punnett squares. For example, if one parent is Bb and the other is Bb, the Punnett square would show 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. This translates to 75% black (BB and Bb) and 25% white (bb), which matches the given ratio. Alternatively, if one parent is Bb and the other is bb, the Punnett square would be 50% Bb (black) and 50% bb (white), which doesn't fit. So the only case where you get 75% black and 25% white is when both parents are Bb, as in option G. Therefore, the parents must be Bb × Bb.

The correct answer is G
